resources.string: The mound made by ants or termites.
A runnable area of rock with no earth or vegetation cover.
Used where a linear feature makes a smooth change of direction; e.g. Path bend; River bend.
Where the control is located underneath the feature; e.g. Pipeline, beneath.
Where the control is located between two features; e.g. Between thickets; Between boulder and knoll.
A small distinct group of boulders so closely clustered together that they cannot be individually mapped.
A prominent free-standing block of rock or stone.
An area covered by so many boulders that they cannot be individually mapped.
A crossing point over a watercourse or other linear feature.
Where the tree or trees associated with the control feature are broad-leaved; e.g. Copse, broad leaved.
Clearly disturbed ground with features too small or too numerous to be mapped individually; including animal earths.
A standing brick, wood or stone structure.
A man made stone or pile of stones. A cairn, memorial stone, boundary stone or trigonometric point.
An accessible area with a roof. A canopy or a covered passageway through a building.
A hole in a rock face or hill side, often leading to underground workings.
The clear remains of an area where charcoal was burned. \n\nA small level man made area on a slope (a platform).
A small area of land free from trees within the forest.
A cliff or rock face. May be passable or impassable.
A small area of trees in open ground.
The point at which two linear features cross.
A way through or over a wall, fence, or other linear feature, including a gate or stile.
Where the control feature is particularly deep but this is not indicated on the map; e.g. Pit, deep.
A depression or hollow from which the ground rises on all sides. Shown on the map with contour lines.
A natural or man made minor water channel which may contain water only intermittently.
An abrupt change in ground level which can clearly be distinguished from its surroundings.
A narrow wall of earth projecting above the surrounding terrain; may be partially stone faced, usually man-made.

Used where:

a) The edge of a feature turns through an angle of 45–135 degrees; e.g. Open land, east corner (inside).

b) A linear feature turns a corner; e.g. Fence, south corner (inside).

Note: The side of a building may be treated as a linear feature and hence “building, east corner (inside)” does not mean “inside the building”. 

The orientation of the symbol indicates the direction in which the corner points.
An erosion gully or trench, normally dry.
A wire or wooden boundary. Used with the Ruined symbol to indicate a ruined fence.
A non-marshy area within a marsh, or between two marshes.
Control site where First Aid is available.
A construction for holding feed for animals.
Where the control is located at the lower junction of the slope of the feature and the surface of the surrounding area and this is not the default location; e.g. Earth bank, foot; Stairway, foot.
The corner or tip of a forested area projecting into open land.
A high point. Shown on the map with contour lines.
The point at which two linear features meet; or where a linear feature meets the side or edge of an areal feature.
A small obvious mound or knoll.
A large area of water, normally mapped as uncrossable.
A man-made line of trees or bushes that is difficult to cross. May also be used for a hedge (typically in Sprint competitions).
Where the control feature is particularly low or flat but this is not indicated on the map; e.g. Hill, low.
Where the control feature is directly below a similar feature.
Where the feature extends over two or more contours and the control is located near the bottom; e.g. Re-entrant, lower part.
A permanently wet area with marsh vegetation.
Where the feature is in an area of marshy ground not indicated on the map; e.g. Re-entrant, marshy.
Where the control feature is the middle one of a number of similar features.
A narrow marsh or trickle of water, too narrow to be shown on the map with the marsh symbol.
A gap between two cliffs or rock faces that face each other.
Where the tree or trees associated with the control feature have needle shaped leaves; e.g. Prominent tree, needle leaved.
As above, but where the feature is large enough for the control to be placed in more than one location around it; e.g. Hill, north east foot.

Used where: 

a) The feature extends above the surface of the ground; e.g. Boulder, north east side; Ruin, west side. A control on the side of a raised feature will not usually be visible from the opposite side. 

b) The control is located on a linear feature but not at a corner, e.g. Track, east side; Stream bend, south west side.
The point at which a linear feature ends or starts; e.g. Ride, north west end; Stone wall, south end.
The more northern of two similar features, or the northern-most of several similar features.
Where the feature is in an area where the tree cover is less than the surroundings but this is not indicated on the map; e.g. Marsh, open.
An area with no trees. Grassland, a meadow or a field. Also heath or moorland.
Out of Bounds area. Typically a flower bed or similar feature.
Where the feature is partially covered in undergrowth or bushes that are not indicated on the map; e.g. Ruin, overgrown.
A visible route made by people or animals. Tracks may be driven by rugged vehicles.
An area of hard standing used for parking or other purposes.
A prominent line feature such as a pipeline (gas, water, oil, etc.) or a bobsleigh/skeleton track which is above ground level.
A pit or hole with distinct steep-sides. Usually man made. Used with symbol 8.6 to indicate a rocky pit.
A small area of water, may be shallow or seasonal.
A power or telephone line, cableway or ski lift.
A support for power or telephone line, cableway or ski lift.
If used, an explanation of its meaning must be supplied to competitors in the pre-race information.
If used, an explanation of its meaning must be supplied to competitors in the pre-race information.
An unusual or prominent tree in either open land or forest; frequently information is also given as to its type.
Gravel, sand or stone working in flat or inclined ground.
A contour indentation; a valley; the opposite of a spur.
Control site where Refreshments are available.
A forest ride or a prominent trace through the terrain which does not have a distinct runnable path along it.
A natural or artificial watercourse with either moving or standing water.
A metalled/asphalt surfaced or dirt road, suitable for vehicles in normal weather conditions.
Where the feature is in an area of rocky or stony ground not indicated on the map; e.g. Pit, rocky.
The upturned root of a fallen tree, with or without the trunk. The stump of a tree.
The remains of a building that has fallen down.
Where the feature has fallen to ground level; e.g. Fence, ruined.
The low point between two higher points.
Where the feature is in an area of sandy ground; e.g. Spur, sandy.
An area of open land with scattered trees or bushes.
Where the control feature is particularly shallow but this is not indicated on the map; e.g. Re-entrant, shallow.
A structure attached to a tree where a marksman or observer can sit.
A small, shallow, natural depression or hollow from which the ground rises on all sides.
A small erosion gully or trench, normally dry.

Used where:

a) The feature extends down from the surface of the surrounding ground and the control is situated on the edge at ground level; e.g. Depression, south east edge.

b) The feature extends over a significant area and the control is situated on the border of that area; e.g. Marsh, west edge; Clearing, north west edge.
The more south eastern of two similar features, or the south-eastern-most of several similar features.

Used where:

a) The edge of a feature turns through an angle of 45–135 degrees; e.g. Ruin, north west corner (outside).

b) A linear feature turns a corner; e.g. Stone wall, south west corner (outside).

The orientation of the symbol indicates the direction in which the corner points.
Used where the edge of a feature turns through an angle of less than 45 degrees; e.g. Marsh, south west tip.
The source of a watercourse with a distinct outflow.
A contour projection or “nose” rising from the surrounding ground.
A stairway of at least two steps.
An area covered with many small stones or rocks.
A level area on a slope.
A small area of forest where the tree cover or undergrowth is so dense that it is difficult to pass. May also be used for an individual bush (typically in Sprint competitions).
Where the control is located at the highest point of the feature and this is not the default location; e.g. Cliff, top; Stairway, top.
A metal, wooden or brick tower or pylon.
A way under roads, railways, etc.
Where the control feature is directly above a similar feature.
Where the feature extends over two or more contours and the control is located near the top; e.g. Erosion Gully, upper part.
A distinct boundary between different types of trees or vegetation.
A wall of stone or other materials. Used with the Ruined symbol to indicate a ruined wall.
A shaft containing water or a captive spring, clearly visible on the ground. Often with some form of man-made surround.
Used where the feature extends over a significant area and the control is located neither at the centre, nor on any of the edges; e.g. Marsh, west part; Depression, south east part.
Height or Depth of the feature in metres.
Horizontal dimensions of the feature in metres.
Height of the feature on a slope in metres.
Heights of two features with the control between them.

The control description sheet lists details of the course and of each control. Each control description is intended to provide details of the flagged feature which are not provided by the map, and to distinguish where the control is placed in relation to the feature.\n\nA sample control description sheet is shown below.
Each column of a control description provides details on a particular aspect of the control or feature.

Numbering of controls is in the sequence they are to be visited, unless the description is for a Score competition in which case this column is usually either left blank or indicates the control value.
The control code should be a number greater than 30.
Column C – Which of any similar feature
This column may be used when there is more than one similar feature within the control circle; e.g. south eastern.

The feature, as shown on the map, at the centre of the circle defining the control site; e.g. clearing; boulder. Most of these are cross referenced to the ISOM 2017 (International Specification for Orienteering Maps) symbol used to represent them.

Further information on the nature of the feature if it is required; e.g. overgrown; ruined. In certain circumstances also used for a second control feature where the description requires this i.e. crossing; junction; between.

Dimensions of the feature should be given where the size of the control feature on the map is symbolic rather than to scale. Also used for the two combination symbols (crossing; junction), and the Bend symbol.
Column G – Location of the control flag
Position of the control flag with respect to the feature; e.g. west corner (outside); south foot.
Other information that may be of importance to the competitor; e.g. first aid; refreshments.
Distance from Timed Start to the Start Triangle

This is an optional line showing the distance to the start triangle from the point of the timed start. This will typically be required for an arena start, or when there is a long run out to the start triangle. It is not required if the start triangle is near to the point where the timing starts.
These lines go in the body of the descriptions and give specific information about the nature of the route that must be followed at that point.
Distance to the start triangle from the point of the timed start.
Follow Taped Route, 120m away from control.
Mandatory passage through out of bounds area.
Follow Taped Route, 60m to Map Exchange.
170m from last control to Finish. Follow taped route.
130m from last control to Finish. Navigate to finish funnel, then follow tapes.
220m from last control to Finish. Navigate to finish. No tapes.

Control description information is from the International Orienteering Federation (IOF) International Specification for Control Descriptions – 2018. Further information can be found at http://www.orienteering.org.
